entry.author: By Tiffany Kary and Thom Weidlich
entry.headline: Judge Rejects Move by Goldman's Tourre to Toss Suit
entry.body:
Goldman Sachs Group Inc. trader Fabrice Tourre’s request to throw out the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission’s lawsuit against him was rejected by a federal judge in New York.

U.S. District Judge Barbara S. Jones today dismissed Tourre’s motion seeking a judgment in the case. He had argued that the SEC can’t sue him over a Goldman Sachs deal involving collateralized debt obligations because the transaction didn’t take place in the U.S.

In the same order, Jones said the SEC can file an amended complaint by Nov. 22.

“Defendant Tourre’s motion for judgment on the pleadings is dismissed without prejudice and with leave to renew after plaintiff has filed its amended complaint,” Jones wrote.

Pamela Chepiga, a lawyer for Tourre, didn’t immediately return a call seeking comment. SEC spokesman John Heine declined to comment.

The U.S. Supreme Court ruled in June that U.S. securities laws don’t apply to claims of foreign buyers of non-U.S. securities on foreign exchanges, lawyers for the Goldman executive director said in a court filing in September. The collateralized debt obligations, known as Abacus, at issue in the SEC’s complaint weren’t listed on any exchange and the sole investor in the notes was a foreign bank that bought them overseas, according to the filing.

Jones said that, because the SEC sued before the Supreme Court decision came out in June, the agency can file an amended complaint.

The case is SEC v. Goldman Sachs, 10-CV-3229, U.S. District Court, Southern District of New York (Manhattan).

To contact the reporter on this story: Tiffany Kary in New York at tkary@bloomberg.net; Thom Weidlich in New York at tweidlich@bloomberg.net.

To contact the editor responsible for this story: David Rovella at drovella@bloomberg.net.

entry.author: By Steven Church
entry.headline: WaMu Accord With JPMorgan, FDIC Was Reasonable, Examiner Reports to Court
entry.body:
Washington Mutual Inc.’s settlement with JPMorgan Chase Co. and federal regulators is reasonable because it will end their court battles over the failure of the biggest U.S. bank, a court-appointed examiner found.

Lawyer Joshua R. Hochberg said fighting JPMorgan and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. in court would put at risk billions of dollars in tax refunds and other assets that could be used to pay creditors.

Continuing to fight, as shareholders have urged, would be “gambling with currently guaranteed recoveries,” Hochberg wrote in a report made public today in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Delaware. “The ultimate resolution of many of the claims could take years.”

WaMu, based in Seattle, has designed a reorganization plan around the settlement, which would bring $7 billion to creditors. Shareholders would be paid nothing.

The shareholders oppose the settlement, arguing that lawsuits could bring enough money to pay off all of WaMu’s debts and still leave something for them.

U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Mary F. Walrath appointed Hochberg and asked him to analyze the proposed settlement. Under WaMu’s reorganization plan, all of the company’s remaining assets would be liquidated and only a reinsurance company would exit bankruptcy.

WaMu filed for bankruptcy on Sept. 26, 2008, the day after its banking unit was taken over by regulators and sold to JPMorgan for $1.9 billion. Before it failed, Washington Mutual Bank had more than 2,200 branches and $188 billion in deposits.

The case is In re Washington Mutual Inc., 08-12229, U.S. Bankruptcy Court, District of Delaware (Wilmington).

To contact the reporter on this story: Steven Church in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Delaware, at schurch@bloomberg.net.

To contact the editor responsible for this story: David E. Rovella at drovella@bloomberg.net.

entry.author: By William McQuillen
entry.headline: Google Sues Interior Department Over Microsoft Bid Requirement
entry.body:
Google Inc., owner of the world’s most popular search engine, sued the U.S. Interior Department, claiming it didn’t provide a “full and open” competition for a messaging-service contract.

In the complaint filed in the U.S. Court of Federal Claims, Google and Onix Networking Corp., a licensed Google seller, seek an order barring the department from proceeding with Microsoft Corp. software without conducting a fair procurement proceeding.

Google, based in Mountain View, California, claims it didn’t have the opportunity to compete for the contract. The Interior Department had been seeking to acquire a single communications service for the agency’s 88,000 users.

“Notwithstanding Google’s efforts and DOI’s assurances to Google representatives that DOI would conduct a full and open competition for its messaging requirements,” the bid request “specified that only the Microsoft Business Productivity Online Suite-Federal could be proposed,” Google wrote in the complaint filed Oct. 29.

The contract is worth $49.3 million over five years, according to the complaint.

An Interior Department spokesman didn’t immediately return a message seeking comment.

The case is Google Inc. v. U.S., 10-743, U.S. Court of Federal Claims (Washington).

To contact the editor responsible for this story: David E. Rovella at drovella@bloomberg.net.

entry.author: By Bill Koenig
entry.headline: JPMorgan, Magnetar CDO Deal Is Under Investigation by SEC, ProPublica Says
entry.body:
The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating a transaction between JPMorgan Chase Co. and the Magnetar Capital hedge fund, ProPublica reported, citing people familiar with the investigation.

The agency is examining whether the hedge fund improperly chose assets for a $1.1 billion deal backed by subprime mortgages, ProPublica said. The deal, known as Squared, was completed in May 2007 and was a collateralized debt obligation comprised of pieces of other CDOs, ProPublica reported.

JPMorgan earned $20 million creating the Squared transaction, ProPublica said, citing an unidentified person involved in the deal. The bank kept portions of Squared on the lender's books and lost about $880 million on the transaction, ProPublica said, without citing a source.

To contact the editor responsible for this story: Bill Koenig at wkoenig@bloomberg.net

entry.author: By Michael P. Regan
entry.headline: U.S. Stocks Erase Gains as Financial, Consumer Shares Retreat
entry.body:
U.S. stocks erased gains as shares of financial and consumer companies turned lower, wiping out an early rally triggered by growth in Chinese manufacturing and speculation the Federal Reserve will announce large-scale asset purchases to pump cash into the economy.

JPMorgan Chase Co. lost 1 percent to pace declines in banks.

The Standard Poor’s 500 Index slipped less than 0.1 percent to 1,182.85 after rallying as much as 1.1 percent earlier.

To contact the editor responsible for this story: Michael Regan at mregan12@bloomberg.net

entry.author: By Steven Church and Jonathan Keehner
entry.headline: Capmark Wins Court Permission to Settle Loan Dispute, Pay Goldman Unit
entry.body:
Capmark Financial Group Inc., the bankrupt commercial lender, won court permission to use most of its remaining cash to pay $835 million to lenders, including affiliates of Goldman Sachs Group Inc.

The payment is part of a settlement between the company and the lenders over a $1.5 billion loan that had been challenged by lower-ranking creditors. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Christopher Sontchi approved the settlement today in an order issued in Wilmington, Delaware.

“Capmark is delighted that this settlement was approved by the bankruptcy court,” said Chief Restructuring Officer Mo Meghji. “I believe this will pave the way for the company to emerge from bankruptcy in the near future.”

Unsecured creditors opposed the settlement, claiming in court papers that the company didn’t fight hard enough to get better terms from the lenders, in part because Capmark is co- owned by New York-based Goldman Sachs.

The creditors also had sought permission to sue the lenders, claiming the loan wasn’t legitimate. Sontchi denied that request.

Capmark, based in Horsham, Pennsylvania, has proposed ending its year-old bankruptcy in part by using almost all of its cash to repay the disputed loan.

Part of the loan already has been repaid, Capmark General Counsel Tom Fairfield said in an interview last week. The company planned to use $750 million in cash, plus another $85 million held in escrow to pay off the loan. Under the settlement, Capmark agreed not sue the lenders over the loan and the lenders agreed to cut as much as $135 million of the principal balance.

Lower-ranking creditors wanted to sue over the loan because they claimed it wrongly swapped unsecured debt for secured debt, giving the lenders a higher repayment priority.

The case is In re Capmark Financial Group Inc., 09-13684, U.S. Bankruptcy Court, District of Delaware (Wilmington).

To contact the reporters on this story: Steven Church in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Delaware, at schurch@bloomberg.net; Jonathan Keehner in New York at jkeehner@bloomberg.net.

To contact the editors responsible for this story: David E. Rovella at drovella@bloomberg.net; David Scheer at dscheer@bloomberg.net.

entry.author: By Ayesha Daya and Anthony DiPaola
entry.headline: Exxon, Shell, Oxy Said to Be Shortlisted for Abu Dhabi Shah Gas
entry.body:
Abu Dhabi shortlisted Exxon Mobil Corp., Royal Dutch Shell Plc and Occidental Petroleum Corp. as potential partners to develop the $10 billion Shah natural-gas project, two people familiar with the plan said.

Abu Dhabi Gas Development Co., owned by Abu Dhabi National Oil Co., known also as Adnoc, is pressing ahead with Shah after the original foreign partner, ConocoPhillips, withdrew from the project in April. The people declined to be identified by name because the decision hasn’t been publicly announced.

The shortlist comes at a time when international companies have limited opportunities to invest in gas projects in a region dominated by state-owned counterparts. By winning the Shah contract, Exxon Mobil, Shell or Occidental would strengthen their presence in the United Arab Emirates, the third-biggest oil producer in OPEC and holder of the fourth-largest gas reserves in the Middle East.

For the sheikhdom of Abu Dhabi, the selection of three candidate partners marks a step toward the emirate’s goal of producing sour, or high-sulfur, gas from Shah as fuel for power plants facing surging demand for electricity.

“This is an extremely vital project to be developed for Abu Dhabi’s future that’s specifically to do with gas demand for the power sector,” said Thaddeus Malesa, an analyst in Dubai with PFC Energy, a consulting firm based in Washington.

Supply Gap

The U.A.E. now imports gas from neighboring Qatar, and it wants to develop nuclear power to help meet local electricity demand, which is expected to double by 2020, according to government studies. Construction of the first nuclear plants won’t begin until 2017, creating a gap in the supply of fuel for the emirate’s power stations that officials hope to fill partly with gas from Shah.

By producing gas locally, Abu Dhabi hopes to save on imported fuel and avoid the more expensive stop-gap solution of burning crude in its power stations, as Saudi Arabia does, Malesa said.

Shah poses a technical challenge because toxic hydrogen sulfide must be separated from the raw gas. The sulfur must then be converted into a solid and transported 250 kilometers (155 miles) to be loaded on ships and exported.

Shell’s Abu Dhabi country chief, John Barry, declined to comment yesterday when asked whether the Anglo-Dutch oil company was on the Shah gas shortlist. Hatem Shaker, an Abu Dhabi-based vice president of public and government affairs for Irving, Texas-based Exxon Mobil, declined to comment.

ConocoPhillips Withdrew

An Occidental public relations official in Abu Dhabi and spokesman Richard Kline at the company’s Los Angeles headquarters also declined to comment.

Abu Dhabi originally chose ConocoPhillips for the project in July 2008, after considering competing bids from Shell and Exxon Mobil, among others. ConocoPhillips withdrew after announcing last October that it planned to divest from some assets and intensify its focus on exploring for oil and gas.

Shell has already studied some of the deposits at Shah and is the most knowledgeable of the three shortlisted companies about the geology there, Malesa said. He added that Shell would probably be Abu Dhabi’s “favorite” as a partner.

“That’s who they want to work with on Shah,” he said. “But I think Shell are worried about what kind of returns they’ll get on the project.”

Bridging Fuel

Shell’s Middle East Vice President for new business Mounir Bouaziz said today in Abu Dhabi that his company had the necessary technology to produce what he called contaminated gas.

“Gas is a key bridging fuel for alleviating some of the power crises we see in the region and in creating a low carbon energy source for countries here,” Bouaziz said.

Occidental, Shell and Exxon are all trying to intensify their gas business in the Gulf, in part because opportunities elsewhere in the Middle East are scarce. Gas projects in Algeria have been delayed, Iran is off limits to Western companies due to economic sanctions, and Iraq is still considered a dangerous place to operate.

Occidental owns 24.5 percent of Dolphin Energy Ltd., an Abu Dhabi state-controlled venture transporting gas from Qatar to the U.A.E. Exxon Mobil is the largest investor in Qatar’s plants that liquefy natural gas for transport by ship. Shell is developing a $19 billion gas-to-liquids plant in Qatar and has a venture with state-owned Saudi Aramco to explore for gas in southern Saudi Arabia.

“We have shortlisted three companies” for Shah, said Mohammed Sahoo, chief executive officer of Abu Dhabi Gas Industries Ltd., another Adnoc unit, speaking in Abu Dhabi today. “We are going ahead with the project.” He declined to name the companies.

Shares Advance

Occidental shares rose 2.1 percent to $80.29, Exxon gained 0.7 percent to $66.97 and Shell increased 1.35 percent to 23.62 euros by 4.17 p.m. London time.

The Shah project, scheduled for completion by the third quarter of 2014, targets processing 1 billion cubic feet of sour gas into 540 million cubic feet a day of fuel. It may also process 4,400 tons a day of natural-gas liquids, 35,000 barrels a day of condensates and 9,200 tons a day of sulfur.

To contact the reporter on this story: Ayesha Daya in Abu Dhabi at adaya1@bloomberg.net. Anthony DiPaola in Abu Dhabi at adipaola@bloomberg.net.

To contact the editor responsible for this story: Stephen Voss at sev@bloomberg.net

entry.author: By Rita Nazareth and Tom Keene
entry.headline: Fed Asset Purchases Could Spark 10% Rally in S&P 500, JPMorgan's Lee Says
entry.body:
The Standard Poor’s 500 Index may rise 10 percent by the end of the year if the Federal Reserve announces plans to buy more bonds to inject money into the economy, a tactic known as quantitative easing, said Thomas J. Lee, chief U.S. equity strategist at JPMorgan Chase Co.

“We’ve already seen some of it in pushing up asset prices or risky assets,” Lee, Wall Street’s most optimistic strategist, said in a Bloomberg Radio interview today with Tom Keene. “QE2 is going to ultimately be very effective. For now, it’s very good for equity markets.”

The SP 500 has risen 14 percent since Fed Chairman Ben S. Bernanke indicated during an Aug. 27 speech in Jackson Hole, Wyoming, that he may be willing to pump more money into the economy. The Fed, which begins a two-day policy meeting tomorrow, has been weighing more monetary injections as its Beige Book business survey released Oct. 20 reported that the economy grew at a “modest pace” in September.

JPMorgan’s Lee said that he favors economically sensitive industries because businesses are gaining more confidence and that should help lift corporate earnings.

“It’s sort of an upside-to-GDP bet,” he said. “We think there’s at least a 9 to 10 percent upside until year end.”

The U.S. economy grew at a 2 percent annual rate in the third quarter as consumer spending climbed the most in almost four years, a sign the expansion is developing staying power. A separate report last week showed business activity unexpectedly accelerated in October.

Earnings Season

Earnings have beaten analysts’ per-share estimates at 259 of the 321 companies in the SP 500 that have reported results since Oct. 7, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. Analysts surveyed by Bloomberg predict an average 28 percent gain in third-quarter profit from a year earlier for all SP 500 companies, and a 36 percent advance for 2010.

Lee increased his combined earnings-per-share forecast for SP 500 companies for 2010 and 2011 to $85.50 and $91, respectively, according to a report dated Oct 28.

The JPMorgan strategist has the highest SP 500 estimate for 2010 among 11 Wall Street strategists tracked by Bloomberg, with a year-end forecast of 1,300. That’s 9.9 percent higher than last week’s closing level, and compares with the average of 1,210.

To contact the reporters on this story: Rita Nazareth in New York at rnazareth@bloomberg.net; Tom Keene in New York at tkeene@bloomberg.net.

To contact the editor responsible for this story: Nick Baker at nbaker7@bloomberg.net.

entry.author: By Jody Shenn
entry.headline: JPMorgan Trims Biggest Mortgage Putback Estimate to $90 Billion
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase Co. analysts lowered their estimate for the cost to sellers of repurchasing soured U.S. mortgages to as much as $90 billion from a range that went as high as $120 billion.

JPMorgan analysts led by John Sim and Ed Reardon removed some potential losses from their previous forecast to account for issuers including New Century Financial Corp. and Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. having failed, they wrote. They also fine-tuned their assumptions for how successful investors may be in winning fights over loans underlying so-called private-label, or non-agency, mortgage bonds, which lack government-backed guarantees.

Future losses from repurchases of home loans whose quality failed to meet sellers’ promises will probably be $40 billion, the analysts wrote in an Oct. 29 report covering debt securitized from 2005 through 2007. On Oct. 15, they forecast likely losses of $55 billion to as much as $120 billion in a “stress” scenario.

“The private-label market typically has the burden to prove, with respect to any given loan, that a breach of a representation or warranty has materially and adversely impacted the value of the loan,” the New York-based analysts wrote.

Mortgage-bond analysts at Bank of America Corp., which along with JPMorgan is among the lenders being targeted by debtholders, said in a report that remaining repurchase losses may total $46 billion. That figure assumes investors in private- label securities seek buybacks on 50 percent of loans that went delinquent in the first two years and succeed with 50 percent of those.

$25.1 Billion

Assuming the bondholders win 25 percent of requests, those New York-based analysts, led by Chris Flanagan, wrote in an Oct. 29 report that losses likely will total $25.1 billion. Their figures also excluded amounts potentially owed by defunct originators and also included mortgages sold to or guaranteed by government-supported Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.

The latest JPMorgan report included an estimate that mortgage-bond investors will seek so-called putbacks on about 25 percent of defaulted mortgages. Because investors will need to demonstrate that misstatements about the quality of loans inflated the debts’ apparent value, the analysts said they adjusted the odds they used for how successful putback attempts will be based on how quickly mortgages went bad.

The analysts assumed that investors’ success rate will be 50 percent for loans that went delinquent in their first 12 months, 40 percent for mortgages whose borrowers stopped paying between one and two years, and 30 percent for loans with later delinquencies, according to their report.

They are also now assuming higher success rates for mortgages whose borrowers were required to provide full documentation of their income and assets, because loans made with less paperwork were “stated as such,” they said.

“Even if buyers claim that fraud was more rampant for limited/no doc loans, they will bear the burden of proving that fraud was committed,” the analysts wrote. “And even if fraud could be proved, not all deals included representations with respect to fraud and not all representations are the same.”

To contact the reporters on this story: Jody Shenn in New York at jshenn@bloomberg.net.

To contact the editor responsible for this story: Alan Goldstein at agoldstein5@bloomberg.net.

entry.author: By Matthew Brown
entry.headline: JPMorgan Recommends Buying Aussie Against U.S. Dollar on Federal Reserve
entry.body:
Investors should buy the Australian dollar against its U.S. counterpart on expectation that the Federal Reserve will step up Treasury purchases after its Nov. 2-3 meeting, according to JPMorgan Chase Co.

“We expect the dollar’s decline to resume should the Fed remove uncertainty and deliver a $500 billion slug of asset purchases next week,” Paul Meggyesi, a managing director of currency strategy at JPMorgan wrote in a research report dated Oct. 29 and sent to journalists today. “The domestic case for further tightening in Australia is largely unanswerable.”

Investors should buy the so-called Aussie at 97.77 U.S. cents and abandon the trade if it weakens to 95.1 cents, Meggyesi said. No estimate of the Aussie’s future value against the dollar was given.

JPMorgan also recommended buying the euro, the Swedish krona and the Korean won against the dollar.

The Australian dollar was 0.5 percent stronger at 98.81 U.S. cents as of 12:18 p.m. in London.

To contact the reporter on this story: Matthew Brown in London at mbrown42@bloomberg.net

To contact the editor responsible for this story: Daniel Tilles at dtilles@bloomberg.net

entry.author: By Isabell Witt and Kate Haywood
entry.headline: Bain Asks JPMorgan, Morgan Stanley to Fund Its Bid for Kate Moss's Priory
entry.body:
Bain Capital LLC, a Boston-based leveraged-buyout firm, asked banks to finance its bid for Priory Group Ltd., an operator of mental-health and addiction clinics whose clients have included Kate Moss and Susan Boyle.

Bain spoke to banks including JPMorgan Chase Co. and Morgan Stanley about the deal, which will include a high-yield bond, according to four people familiar with the matter. Bank of America Corp. and Priory’s owner, Royal Bank of Scotland Group Plc, are also negotiating roles, said three of the people, who declined to be identified because the talks are private.

Leveraged-buyout companies announced $51 billion of acquisitions Europe this year, compared with $15 billion a year earlier, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. LBO debt is raised in the name of the target company and repaid with its cash flow, triggering a fall in its credit rating to junk.

“There is improved interest” in LBO debt, “albeit more on a name-by-name basis versus the carte-blanche approach of a few years back,” said Jonathan Moore, a high-yield analyst at Evolution Securities Ltd. in London.

Bain is the frontrunner to buy Priory after RBS’s talks with other private-equity firms including Cinven Ltd., Advent International Corp. and Blackstone Group LP failed. Priory attracted offers of less than 1 billion pounds ($1.6 billion), though Edinburgh-based RBS had been seeking about 1.1 billion pounds, people familiar with the matter said in September.

Photographer: Rick Maiman/Bloomberg News

entry.author: By Rakteem Katakey
entry.headline: ONGC Videsh Studying Proposal Offering Exxon Mobil's Stake in Angola Field
entry.body:
ONGC Videsh Ltd., a unit of India’s biggest energy exploration company, is studying a proposal from bankers offering Exxon Mobil Corp.’s stake in a field in Angola.

“It’s too early to comment,” Managing Director R.S. Butola said in New Delhi today, responding to an Economic Times report that Oil Natural Gas Corp. may buy Exxon Mobil’s 25 percent stake in a deepwater field in Angola for $2 billion. No decision has been taken on pricing or bidding, he said, without identifying the bankers.

State-owned ONGC leads India’s push to secure energy supplies overseas for the world’s third-fastest-growing major economy. India’s demand for oil and gas will increase 40 percent in the next 10 years, Prime Minister Manmohan Singh said at a conference in New Delhi today. In its quest for supplies, India has lost out to China in at least $12.5 billion of contracts in the year ended June 30.

“A deal like this will be positive for ONGC,” said Vinay Nair, a Mumbai-based analyst with Khandwala Securities Ltd. “They need to add to their oil and gas resources especially since they haven’t been too successful domestically.”

ONGC shares rose 1.3 percent to 1,320.90 rupees at 1:59 p.m. in Mumbai trading. The stock has climbed 12 percent this year compared with a 17 percent advance in the benchmark Sensitive Index.

ONGC Videsh is expected to submit a bid soon, the Economic Times reported, citing two unidentified people with direct knowledge of the matter. The field may produce 300,000 barrels a day by 2012, according to the report, which cited the website of the U.S. Energy Information Administration.

Block Partners

BP Plc is the operator of the Block 31 field, and its partners include Statoil ASA, Total SA and Angola’s state-run oil company, Sonangol SA, the newspaper said.

“In Block 31, some of the companies are leaving, and Sonangol has the responsibility to find other partners,” Angolan Oil Minister Jose Maria Botelho de Vasconcelos told reporters in New Delhi today.

India’s prime minister said his government is encouraging national oil companies to invest in foreign oil and gas projects. “We seek to build strong economic partnerships with other countries and their oil and gas industries to the mutual benefit of each other,” Singh said.

Sovereign Fund

The South Asian nation has proposed a sovereign wealth fund to bid for reserves and has told ONGC and its smaller state- owned rival Oil India Ltd. to make one major acquisition each this year. Both companies have a mandate to raise the amount they can spend without government approval to 50 billion rupees ($1.1 billion).

ONGC is working with Vietnam Oil Gas Group, also known as PetroVietnam, for the purchase of BP’s assets in Vietnam. The British company’s stake in projects has been offered to its Russian oil venture, Moscow-based TNK-BP.

India is in talks for its state explorers to form a partnership with the winner of development rights to the Trebs and Titov fields, Russia’s largest undistributed oil assets, Oil Secretary S. Sundareshan said in an interview Oct. 27.

ONGC bought Imperial Energy Plc, which has oil fields in Siberia, for about 1.4 billion pounds ($2.2 billion) last year.

To contact the reporter on this story: Rakteem Katakey in New Delhi at rkatakey@bloomberg.net.

To contact the editor responsible for this story: Amit Prakash at aprakash1@bloomberg.net.

entry.author: By Simeon Bennett
entry.headline: ResMed Shares Fall After Goldman Sachs Cuts Rating on Weaker Sales Outlook
entry.body:
ResMed Inc. fell the most in more than 17 months in Australian trading after Goldman Sachs Group Inc. cut its rating on the stock to “hold,” citing a weaker- than-expected sales outlook for the company.

ResMed, the world’s second-biggest maker of machines to overcome night-time breathing disorders, declined 4.1 percent to A$3.27 as of the 4:10 p.m. close in Sydney, the most since May 11 last year. The benchmark SP/ASX 200 Index rose 0.8 percent.

Slower industry growth and softer economic conditions have prevented the Poway, California-based company from achieving the same sales growth with new products as it had previously, Ian Abbott and Andrea Chong, health-care analysts at Goldman in Melbourne, wrote in a note today. They cut their rating from “buy” and maintained a 12-month stock-price estimate of A$4.

ResMed said Oct. 29 that fiscal first-quarter net income jumped 35 percent on sales of its S9 Autoset and Elite products that regulate breathing for people with sleep apnea. While sales of the devices have “not yet reached full momentum,” revenue growth of 20 percent or more is “unrealistic in the near term,” Abbott and Chong said.

The company’s sales growth averaged 21 percent in the five years ended June 30, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

To contact the reporter on this story: Simeon Bennett in Singapore at sbennett9@bloomberg.net

To contact the editor responsible for this story: Jason Gale at j.gale@bloomberg.net.

entry.author: By Bloomberg News
entry.headline: Shanghai Pudong Road Gains Most in Shanghai on Disney Prospects
entry.body:
Shanghai Pudong Road Bridge Construction Co. jumped by the maximum 10 percent limit on speculation it will benefit from construction on Walt Disney Co.’s theme park in the city.

Shanghai Pudong gained 10 percent to 16.36 yuan at 1:06 p.m. local time. Shanghai Construction Co. rose 8 percent to 14.68 yuan.

“The two stocks surged probably because of speculation that construction on Shanghai Disney park will start soon and the companies stand to win project contracts,” Luo Guo, an analyst at Orient Securities Co., said by phone.

Pudong Road said one of its units won two contracts valued at 1 billion yuan to build roads in Pudong district, according to an exchange filing on Sept. 29. The Oriental Morning Post reported on Sept. 30 the contracts are part of Shanghai Disney park construction projects. Theme park construction starts this month after the conclusion of the World Expo, the Shanghai Securities News reported on Oct. 18,

To contact the editor responsible for this story: Allen Wan at awan3@bloomberg.net

entry.author: By Ketaki Gokhale
entry.headline: Indian Software Companies Will Press Obama on Visa Restrictions
entry.body:
Indian software executives plan to press President Barack Obama to avoid further tightening of U.S. visa requirements for foreign workers that threatens the growth of the industry.

Nasscom, the group representing Indian software companies such as Tata Consultancy Services Ltd. and Infosys Technologies Ltd., will meet with Obama during his India visit this weekend to lobby against legislation to add additional fees and penalties to working visas for non-U.S. citizens.

India’s outsourcing industry has swelled 15-fold over the last ten years as U.S. companies including General Electric Co. and Citigroup Inc. have used it to cut costs. With U.S. unemployment near a 26-year high, Obama has doubled the fees for working visas, costing the industry as much as $250 million annually.

“The visa issue is significant for a very simple reason -- it indicates a mindset of protectionism,” said T.V. Mohandas Pai, head of human resources development at Bangalore-based Infosys, India’s second-biggest software maker. “You want the markets to be open. The only way for the world economy to grow is to keep them open.”

Pending immigration legislation in the U.S. Congress includes a bill sponsored by Illinois Senator Dick Durbin and New Jersey Representative Bill Pascrell, to make it harder for employers to obtain the skilled worker visas by adding new requirements, fees and penalties to the program.

On-site Staff

India-based companies that win outsourcing contracts need U.S. visas as some clients ask for on-site staff to work as coordinators and provide technical support. Apart from the visa program, the Indian I.T. industry has created 35,000 jobs for U.S. residents in the last five years, according to Nasscom.

“There are many data points that say Indian I.T. is the wrong target, but it’s just a very visible one and a good whipping boy for job loss and bringing jobs back,” said Partha Iyengar, head of research at Gartner Inc. in Mumbai.

The Indian government has described the additional visa costs as “highly discriminatory.”

Adding to the industry’s concerns, Ohio issued an executive order banning the use of public funds for outsourced services on Aug. 6.

“We must do everything within our power to prevent outsourcing jobs because it undermines our economic development objectives, slows our recovery and deprives Ohioans and other Americans of employment opportunities,” the government said.

Other States

“There’s some level of concern that that should not spread,” said P.R. Chandrasekar, chief executive officer of Hexaware Technologies Ltd., an Indian software developer backed by private equity firm General Atlantic LLC. “You don’t want other states to do that, other sectors to do that.”

GE founded a back-office in Gurgaon, India in 1997 to serve its finance unit. In 2004, it sold 60 percent of the unit, now called Genpact, for $500 million to General Atlantic and Oak Hill Capital Partners LP.

Citigroup also owned a back-office unit in India that it sold to Tata Consultancy in 2008 for $505 million and orders worth $2.5 billion over 9 1/2 years.

Indian technology companies used approximately 4,800 new H- 1B visas in fiscal year 2009, which equals to 0.003 percent of the U.S. civilian labor force, according to an Aug. 12 report from the U.S. Chamber of Commerce.

New Contracts

The industry is still winning contracts in North America, according to Chandrasekar. The company added its first government contracts in North America, two “small” deals with a state government, in the September quarter, he said.

Eight of the company’s 13 new customers added in the quarter were based in North America, and the share of North America revenue increased to 67 percent in the quarter, from 64.5 percent a year earlier, he said.

Indian executives say the U.S. unemployment rate, which stood at 9.6 percent as of the end of September, makes it unlikely their views will prevail. Economists surveyed by Bloomberg last month said U.S. gross domestic product growth rate will be 2.7 percent in 2010. India’s government expects the economy to expand 8.5 percent in the year through March.

“The rhetoric has been worsening,” said Pai of Infosys. “It’s a function of the economic environment.”

entry.headline: JPMorgan Buys $513 Million in Lehman Brothers Claims From Frank Russell
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase Co. bought $513 million in claims on Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. from Frank Russell Co., court filings show.

The claims consisted of Lehman commercial paper, according to today’s filings in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan.
